Blog.post: The following are stories I've written for a weekly column in our Sunday bulletin at NewStart. When I was five I cheerfully stood by and watched my three-year-old sister get a spanking for something I did. My mother thought my sister did it, and I didnât bother correcting her. A five-year-oldâs sins arenât as impressive as an adultâs, but they are just as contrary to love. When I was six I told Jesus I was sorry and asked him to help me be good. Suddenly I felt so clean and free. The sky literally looked bluer and the grass greener than Iâd ever noticed before. I felt lighter than air. When I was 12 I realized that even though I wanted to love like God loved, my heart was still different from his and we struggled a lot. I then surrendered absolutely and completely to his love and he filled and changed my heart in a way that carried me through all the turmoil of adolescence. I found a joy and a peace that were ââ and are ââ indescribable. I have had worries and struggles and hard times since then. I have failed and messed up since then. But God hasnât. That was over 40 years ago, and his love for me seems sweeter than ever. Every time I discover another old hurt or a new fear, he takes it and heals it or conquers it and drives it out with his love. I highly recommend complete surrender to the love of God. For years Michael Payne struggled with severe clinical depression, failed marriages and rejection by churches. Then NewStart sent out a couple of mailers the week before Easter of 1999. Michael received one of them, and cried when he read the challenge to hope again. He recognized in our dream the cry of his own heart. Iâm so glad he did. At NewStart he experienced the overwhelming love of God for him. He began to find healing from the depression, new joy and purpose and a renewed capacity to give and receive love. God has given Michael the gift of encouragement. He can consistently be counted on to contact and affirm our NewStart family members who are struggling, stressed, sick or just absent from our fellowship. He continually expresses to us the love that God has placed in his heart. He has become a dear friend and brother. Surely some of Godâs greatest moments must include Michael Payne. When we talk about âGodâs Greatest Momentsâ itâs easy to focus on the dramatic crisis encounter, or the people with the showy gifts or loud personalities. Itâs easy to miss the real backbone of an organization, who stands in the shadows and quietly keeps it all functioning. Darrell Bohannan is our church treasurer, with all the headaches and responsibilities that entails. Three months after the Hearns arrived in the United States we still didnât have a core group committed to starting a new church in Frisco. Neither the Hearns nor Mercers lived in Frisco, yet. We decided to put together a âpresentation serviceâ to show the Nazarene churches in the area what we envisioned. Darrell attended that very first service on June 13, 1998 . When we met for three introductory meetings in downtown Frisco immediately after that, he was there. At the end of that third meeting he committed himself to membership and identification with the dream of NewStart. When we met in homes, or in another church, Darrell was there. When we went through the darkest times, personally and in terms of the vision, Darrell was there. When we needed someone to tell us we were on the right track and that it wasnât crazy to take the next big leap, Darrell was there. In all this time, at every victory and in every moment of doubt, Darrell has so quietly been there, supporting and believing, that we hardly recognize how much we lean on him. Surely, when God brought Darrell Bohannan to us, that was one of âGodâs greatest moments.â She came to us with English as a second language and uncertain what to expect of this new church. But she came with a quick, open mind and a sensitive, perceptive heart. And how remarkably God has filled that mind and heart! She has told of how God has given her a new joy and a new family ââ both at NewStart and at home. She brought her husband and her children and her friends and her relatives. She came with her hopes and fears and strengths and struggles. With all the passion that is characteristic of her approach to everything, she has thrown herself into the arms of a loving God. She has preached with conviction and insight. She has ministered encouragement to people who needed encouragement. She has cared for our children. She has helped us dream our future. She has become a close friend and a genuine sister to me and others. She has inspired and equipped others for extraordinary ministry. She prays with discernment and power. The joy and intimacy of her relationship with God are compelling and contagious. She has become a true spiritual leader and example at NewStart. She is proof to me, personally, that everything I have believed about God is true. I am eternally grateful that God brought Karin Hiort to NewStart. Roland had been here four months and we didnât have a church yet. That wasnât unusual, but we didnât know that. The core group of existing Nazarenes that we had expected to materialize as a nucleus for the new church â hadnât. It was the longest that Roland and Emmy had ever been away from home and the cultural adjustments were greater than expected. Satan was attacking them in fierce, unexpected ways. In the middle of that dark time, Roland met a guy named Don Crecelius and told him about our vision. With nothing to show him in support of the vision, Don announced that he would be part of that non-existent church. That struck me like the thief on the cross who told Jesus âremember me when you come into your kingdomâ when every indication was that there wasnât going to be any kingdom. It represented simply stunning faith. Roland took the pronouncement with a grain of salt, but Don was even better than his word. When, after several months of meeting in someone elseâs church building or private home, we finally found the building we meet in today, it was totally unsuitable for our purposes. Don walked in and mapped out an appropriate floor plan on a napkin the first time he saw it. He procured the labor, materials, and permits and did much of the work with his own hands. And he brought it in on time and under budget. He has loved us like a brother. He has led our menâs Bible study. He has shared our laughter and tears, and shared his own with us. His enthusiasm and confidence in God have lifted us when we were down. He is that rarest of treasures, an absolutely trustworthy and absolutely unshakable friend. He is one of Godâs greatest gifts to NewStart and to me. If youâve been a part of NewStart very long youâve heard this story, but I want to tell it again here. Roland Hearn and I met on a Nazarene discussion board on the internet. I was immediately drawn to his sense of humor and his passion for God and his creative vision for how to minister the forgiving, healing grace of God to a hurting world. When I was 20 years old I read in Readerâs Digest that when a man is 20 years old he wants to save the world, but when heâs 40 heâs happy if he can just save part of his paycheck. I was 40 when Roland and I met, and I was just about there. I still ranted and raved about passion and idealism, but I did it all from the safety of the Sunday School class in my nice, big, established church. I will always count Rolandâs place in my life as one of my greatest encounters with God. By leaving his own country and all that he held dear in order to pursue the vision of a church that effectively led people to a radical, healing, transforming encounter with God, Roland dared me to âput up or shut up.â God used him to rekindle in a 40-year-old man a young manâs dream that saving the world was still a purpose to which I might legitimately give my life. I pray that this morningâs service may in some small way begin to do the same thing in your heart. I have watched God transform Steve Montagueâs life at NewStart Church of the Nazarene â Frisco. I knew him at Richardson Church of the Nazarene and I knew he sang and was single, but that was about it. I donât remember ever actually hearing him sing and I didnât know his story. I do now, and itâs a marvelous story. The very first time we tried to show the Dallas District of the Church of the Nazarene the kind of services we had in mind for NewStart, Steve was in the service, on June 13, 1998 . Heâs been here ever since, although I didnât really know why at first. But I have felt chills up and down my spine and my heart swell with love for him and our Abba Daddy as I have watched God unfold his precious heart since then. My heart has been drawn into the Holy of Holies in worship by Steveâs voice, and by his tears. Iâve watched him become increasingly free and comfortable as he leads us in worship and Iâve given thanks to God. Iâve listened to him at a retreat or a home group tell of his journey from hopelessness to hope and I have fallen in love with him and with his God. Iâve watched him become a brother to my sisters and to me. I am eternally grateful for his encounters with God at NewStart. It is my great privilege to have encountered God through Steve Montague. Fourteen years ago I went to Belize , Central America to help fix up a poor church leaderâs house there. I scraped and painted along with others who performed various repair tasks inside the house, while a crew of three guys re-roofed the house under the hot tropical sun. We had the easy job. They were badly sunburned and way past what I would have considered the point of absolute physical exhaustion before they were done. One of those guys was Curt Crawford. Someone else paid my way, but he paid his own way to work and suffer, out of love for Christ and the church and the people of Belize . Later, he was my Sunday School teacher. I watched him grow on the job until he was a master at drawing out the quiet people while keeping the talkative ones like me under control, all the while drawing out new insights into the character of God from a scripture. When I became dissatisfied with my job he volunteered to help me update a resume and network with potential employers. He has consistently taught me by his words and by his actions what it means to be a gracious Christian gentleman. I am deeply grateful after all these years to still encounter God through Curt Crawford. NewStart sent out a mailer in September of 1999, inviting Frisco to our new church. One of the people who came was Steve Steen, a child psychologist with a lot of pain in his life and a fair bit of suspicion toward God and church. Over the following three years I got to participate in conversations with Steve in which he made probing, challenging critiques of what we were about and asked hard, honest questions about what we believed about the character of God. At the same time, he was equally honest as he looked at his own heart and the hopes and fears and assumptions he found there. I have watched Steveâs analytical mind and tender heart embrace God and us. I have watched him deliberately invite God deeper and deeper into his life. Iâve watched him begin to draw others into the love of God, ministering grace to his own clients and family. He has become a friend and a brother and an inspiration to me. In the Bible, the highest and final credit Jesus gives to those who love him is that they fed the hungry, and in so doing, they fed him. Steve has fed me when I was hungry. He has valued me when I didnât feel valuable. I have encountered God through Steve Steen. Iâve written here the stories of people of NewStart, people from the Bible and early Nazarenes who have shaped my understanding of God. Is it okay in such a column to write about my own wife? I have been loved more deeply, more purely, more sacrificially, more sensitively, more passionately and more consistently by Karen Mercer than by anyone else in my life. I have encountered God and come to better understand his character through Karenâs love for me. She has cheered me on and believed in me when I struggled to achieve something. I think God must be like that. She has believed the best of me when the best was true, even when others didnât. She has loved and understood and sympathized and forgiven when the best wasnât true. I am confident that God is like that. She has received my best with joy and pride even when my best wasnât really very impressive. She has shown me who needed love and how to love them. She has loved others on my behalf, in ways that I could not. Iâm so glad. I have encountered God in my marriage. I think thatâs what he intended. Intelligent, good-looking, successful, heâd never really felt much need for religion. He made a deal with his wife, though, that â just this one time -- heâd try the new church she was all excited about. If he didnât like it theyâd find something else to do together on Sundays. He was pretty sure he wouldnât like it. He was wrong â about liking the new church and about needing âreligion.â Christer Hiort unexpectedly encountered his heavenly father, and he fell completely in love. Very much against his expectations, Christer fell in love like he never had before in his life. He discovered that when he stumbles, God is eager and able to pick him up again. He discovered that the love of God is able to help him to stand. He fell head over heels in love with God. He fell more deeply and more purely in love with his wife than he had ever been before. He fell in love with his kids all over again. In great, mighty, astonishing leaps he grew in love and in knowledge and in wisdom. Along the way, he became a precious, treasured brother to me and others. He ministers to us and he confirms for us the grace and power of God. I am so grateful for my encounters with God through Christer. One of the great joys of being a part of the family of God, and especially of being a part of a local community of faith, is having our own faith confirmed by seeing God at work in the lives of people around us, just as He has worked in ours. When we let God work in our own lives, we also participate with Him in the work He desires to do in other people, because they get to see Him reflected in us. I have seen Christ in Jim Sublette. I have seen him reflect everything that NewStart is about. He has confirmed my faith in what God desires to do in my life and in my church. I have seen him be open and honest and vulnerable about his doubts, his struggles, his pain and his past. When he wanted to walk away Iâve seen him instead choose to trust God and embrace love and relationship at new levels. Iâve seen his family growing spiritually as he has lead by example. We have laughed together and cried together and worked and played together. And I have seen Christ in Jim Sublette. He has become a vital part of what God is doing and is going to do here. He leads us in worship as a part of our Sunday morning worship team. Hehas worked behind the sceneson our website so that it becomes a more effective community-building tool for NewStart. His tender heart makes the menâs Saturday morning Bible study a holy place. He has led us to be accountable and to keep our promises. We are privileged to see God reflected in our friend and brother Jim Sublette. Rick Milnes has been a part of NewStart since September, 1999. I have encountered God through Rick. He has shared with us his pain and struggles, his gifts and talents. Iâve watched him sing songs of worship with tears in his eyes, and seen grace at work. Iâve watched him laughing with the kids from the platform and seen the love of God reflected in him. Since Rick joined us Iâve watched him raise questions and seen his open heart receive new truth. Iâve heard him humbly confess his failures and receive grace. During all that time, as we have laughed together and cried together, worshiped together and played together, I have watched Rick grow in the likeness of Christ, more than he probably recognizes. He remains very humble about his spiritual walk. But I have loved watching Rickâs heart grow softer and more radiant as he eagerly embraces every new step in his journey with God. Rick is an inspiration and a blessing to me. I gratefully count him a brother. The earliest converts are extraordinarily encouraging to the hopes of a new church. When someone new comes into our circle and, maybe for the first time, begins to hope that God might, after all, be a God of love and integrity, and we begin to see healing happen, it reaffirms and encourages our own faith as little else can. I have encountered God through my friendship with Will Presnall. He was an atheist who said heâd never go to church. But God had been preparing Willâs brilliant, probing, analytical mind to receive grace long before he came to NewStart. And from the very first Sunday he visited our services, I saw his heart begin to confirm the truths his mind had already grasped. He immediately began to pour himself into seeking more grace, and to building relationships in places like Sunday night home group and the Saturday morning menâs Bible study. Now, he and Lori can lead a Bible study like theyâve been doing it all their lives. Iâve seen a deepening peace in his face, and heard a more confident joy develop in his voice, and noted in his behavior a heightened awareness of the needs and value of the people around him. Will is a brother to me. I have encountered God in him. I was amazed. I didnât think public school teachers were allowed to do the things this young woman in her 20's talked about doing with her students. She taught math, but she also cried with those kids and listened to them and loved them and brought them to Jesus. I remember going with her to a poor, south Dallas neighborhood to help a Hispanic family, and painting a house with her in Central America . One of the phrases sometimes used to describe the result of the relationship with God we preach about at NewStart is âradical optimism.â She personified that trait. As the years passed I watched her struggle with the hurts that sooner or later come into everyoneâs life, like her motherâs slow, painful death. I watched her being beaten down by other hurts that seem especially to happen in the church. Iâve watched her struggle against anger and bitterness and cynicism and disillusionment. And Iâve watched her win. Iâve watched her come through the hurts of life with her radical optimism and love and joy and hope reborn, stronger and more beautiful than ever. Now she is one of our pastors at NewStart. My wife Karen and I named our daughter Charlotte Denise Mercer after her, and Iâm glad our daughter has such role models. I have encountered God through Denise Crawford over and over again for years. Iâm glad that our adoption into the family of God gives me the right to call her my sister. Amber Rogde was employed by a Nazarene University in Oklahoma when she discovered NewStart. She immediately and unhesitatingly embraced the paradigm of love that she found here. She quit her job and moved here, at least in part to become a part of this fellowship and help us fulfill the vision God has given us. I have watched her bare her soul before God and the family of God. I have seen Christ in her as she has allowed him to heal her hurts. I have seen Christ in her as she has related to me with sisterly compassion and concern when I was hurting. I have seen Christ in her when she has led us into worship through the music on Sunday morning. I have seen Christ in her as she has modeled to our children what it means to be children of God. In her laughter and in her tears, I have encountered God through Amber. Iâm so glad I get to be a part of a family and a church made up of people like her. Karin Hiort never really had much to do with church, and recent visits to churches had not impressed her much, but she was hungry for God. Karin had a friend named Lori Presnall. Lori was tired and discouraged and wasnât experiencing the love of God very fully in the church she was attending, but she nevertheless encouraged Karin to find a church where she could experience God and find the desires of her heart met. Karin did. She found God at NewStart and told Lori about it. Since the Pressnalls became a part of our life I have seen God in Lori. I have seen his grace at work in how she came to us. I have seen her dear, sweet, sad face begin to light up. I have seen God begin to restore to her his love and joy and peace and hope. Her faithfulness has encouraged me. Her willingness to allow God to work his transforming grace in her heart and in her marriage has inspired me. Her smile and her tears have touched my heart. I have encountered God in Lori Presnall. I am glad our heavenly father has made her a sister to me.

Christer was Contract Director for Swedish-based telecommunications giant Ericsson. His employer had transferred him from his native Sweden to Saudi Arabia, Holland and now Texas. He had a successful career, a wonderful wife and children, good health and a nice home. His wife Karin was a teacher. They thought about God only vaguely if at all, and viewed the church as irrelevant and alien at best, and oppressive and foolish at worst. Prosperous and apparently socially and emotionally secure, Christer and Karin, like most Swedes and perhaps most Europeans, were thoroughly secular and thoroughly post-modern in their worldview and cultural perspectives. Karin, however, was spiritually searching. She was a voracious reader who had concluded from her eclectic religious and philosophical readings that God was more a force than a person, and prayer was âchanneling love energy.â Then, in April of 1999, she received an arresting piece of junk mail. Splattered at random across the page were words like loneliness, alienation, self-loathing, rage and despair. At the bottom of the page was the challenge to âdare to hope again, one more time.â With some trepidation, she took the challenge and attended the first public service of NewStart Church of the Nazarene in Frisco, Texas, an upscale suburb of Dallas. She expressed pleasant surprise after the service that we hadnât verbally attacked homosexuals, or done any of the other things sheâd apparently expected of an American Protestant church. A few weeks later she brought her husband with her. He agreed to attend just that once, and if he didnât like it, she agreed that theyâd find something else to do as a family on Sundays thereafter. As it turned out, he did like it. He expressed surprise that the Christians he met at NewStart were more intelligent than heâd expected. In the weeks to follow they developed close, deep friendships with several other people in the church. A few months later, Karin accepted Christ in a womenâs weekday Bible study. A few months after that, Christer accepted Christ in the home of Pastor Roland Hearn. A few months later, they were each sanctified, separately, in their own prayer times. Along the way, with little or no prompting from anyone but the Holy Spirit, sins and vices dropped away. Everything but perfect love was crowded out of their hearts. They told us they had never experienced such love. As time passed, they would come to us and tell us âI will never forget this dayâ and âThis has been the best week of my lifeâ and then âThis has been the best year of my life.â They both now serve on our church board, are both taking classes in the ministerial course of study and have both preached in our Sunday morning services at NewStart. Theyâve attended district assemblies and a general assembly and have conducted Swedish-language services at NewStart for the Swedish community in north Dallas. Numerous friends and relatives in Sweden, after attending NewStart while on vacation in Texas, and seeing the transformation in Karinâs and Christerâs lives, now eagerly await the planting of a church like NewStart in Sweden someday. One after another, through the doors of NewStart have come a steady succession of similar stories of people who were educated and successful and on the outside appeared to have no need, but on the inside felt empty and worthless and purposeless and in pain. An engineer, a project manager, an executive, a psychologist, a salesman, a housewife, a single parent, they brought every dysfunction imaginable to NewStart Church of the Nazarene and to God: alcoholism, drug addiction, sexual addictions, personality disorders, eating disorders, suicidal depression and self-mutilation as well as obsessions with careers and money. Most of them knew little or nothing about God and the Christian church and what they did know they didnât like. Now they are a glorious church, without spot or wrinkle, washed in the blood of the lamb. Now a holiness people, committed to the world-wide vision of the Church of the Nazarene, they live in deep, pure, intimate, honest, vulnerable, loving relationships as brothers and sisters, sharing in all the struggles and victories of the spirit-filled life in this fallen world. NewStart-Frisco began with no core group and no financial support except a pastoral salary from the district. We started with the pastor and one layman and a paradigm for translating the message of holiness into the language of the developed world in the 21st Century. We never denounced a single sin in a Sunday morning service, never preached about money or stewardship, and never passed an offering plate. A little over three years after our launch, though, we were a fully organized, fully self-supporting church of seventy people who are being set free from sin and set free to love. We are growing numerically, financially and spiritually. We are in love with God, each other and the denomination. We are united in our excitement about, and commitment to, the vision that God has given us. We believe that it is a vision that is transferable to Sweden, Holland or our pastorâs homeland in Australia as readily as to the neighboring suburbs of north Dallas. That vision â that paradigm â is essentially this: We start with the objective truth, found in I John 4:8 and 4:16 that âGod is love.â We recognize that love has no value for us until it is recognized, received and experienced. If love means anything at all, it must mean something about value. If we say we love something, we mean it has value to us. Jesus says of us in Matthew 10:31: âdonât be afraid; you are more valuable to him than a whole flock of sparrows.â Being born in sin must at least in part mean to be born without the knowledge that God is love, and without the knowledge that we are innately valuable to him. Our sinful acts may to some degree be recognized as the search for a sense of self-worth in the absence of God, or as the search for a way to medicate the pain of feeling worthless. We are isolated and disconnected and without the capacity to love and be loved â to live in intimate relationship as we were designed to live. We donât and canât love God with all our heart, soul, mind and strength, or our neighbor as ourselves. To fulfill the greatest commandment, and the second one that is like it, means to live in deep, pure, perfect love relationship with God and each other. We are born for relationship. It is our destiny. We have no other or higher purpose. As a church, we have no other purpose but to model those relationships in such a way as to draw people to Christ, who alone can restore them to those relationships which are the cry of their hearts. We are to spend our lives modeling and nurturing those restored relationships. In that context alone can we find holiness, healing and spiritual growth. As we were planting NewStart Church of the Nazarene in Frisco, we tried to think through all of the issues, practices, programs, structures and language of the local church in terms of that fundamental understanding. Are we, in everything we say and do as a church, effectively communicating that fundamental understanding to the world, or even to each other, here and now, today? We decided that if âgospelâ is just a Greek word for the English phrase âgood news,â then any time the message of the church didnât sound like good news, we werenât saying it right. Those basic ideas, when really worked through to their ultimate, practical conclusion in all the details of church life, have utterly transformed the way we do church. Of course, one of the wonderful spin-offs for Roland and me, as third-generation Nazarenes, is the confirmation of everything weâve always most treasured at the heart of what it means to be a Nazarene. We get to see first-hand the truth and the power of entire sanctification, of heart holiness, and of the radical optimism of Wesleyanism. Sometimes these new Nazarenes, so very different in so many ways, describe their new life in Christ even in the same words that Phineas Bresee and Buddie Robinson used, before theyâve ever even heard of those men. If those core truths are going to impact our culture as profoundly as they impacted Breseeâs and Uncle Buddieâs, though, we have to understand, not only those truths, but our own culture, as well as they did. The church many of us grew up in was built by the generation before the Baby Boomers â the âBuilder Generation.â From political parties to civic clubs to fraternal organizations to churches, they were âjoiners.â They felt valued by being admitted into an exclusive circle, with impressive ceremony. As the nickname of that generation suggests, they were builders. They expressed value for their neighbor by raising a barn or for their family by naming a business after themselves â Sons.â They built edifices and monuments as a way of saying âthis is important. These people or ideas have value.â They respected authority and hierarchy, and wanted a title and a sense of active rank within the hierarchy. Structure, rules, titles and clearly-defined roles for everyone represented a way to artificially replace the ancient sense of order and belonging that were being lost in a rapidly industrializing and urbanizing world. The Nazarene church of 50 or 100 years ago did a brilliant job of expressing holiness â perfect love â in forms that the culture around them could readily find compelling. As a result, the church grew impressively in numerical terms, and a generation grew up routinely hearing fresh testimonies of the experience of full salvation. The urban and suburban culture of the 21st Century Information Age is very different from the rural and small-town culture of the 19th and 20th Century Industrial Age, but our charge as Nazarenes is the same: to be like the men of Issachar in I Chronicles 12:32, âwho understood the times, and knew what Israel should do.â To communicate perfect love as effectively to our generation as our grandfathers did to theirs, we must understand the times. Generation X, even more than the Boomer generation, values experience over theory, consensus over authority and belonging over joining. Itâs not enough for us that an idea sounds good; we have to be able to make it our own in a practical way. We have to be able to see that it works. Experience, of course, is one leg of the Wesleyan quadrilateral, so in this, our generation is more amenable to Wesleyanism than previous generations. âQuestion Authorityâ has been the mantra of Western culture since the 1960âs, so we tend, in pretty much any forum, whether work, government or church, to just instinctively bristle when someone expects us to believe or do something solely on the basis of some asserted authority. We expect to be empowered to think for ourselves, and valued for our capacity to do so. Weâll all pursue a course of action together because we are all heard, and thrash through the ideas together until we reach a consensus, not just because the leader lays it all out for us. Finally, we are hesitant to formally âjoinâ any organization as a âdues-paying member.â To join is to submit to authority and duty. Perhaps there was a time when we felt valued by being taken under someoneâs wing, but today we are skeptical and fearful of being expected to âcheck our brains at the door.â Yet somehow we still want to belong â to be in deep, real, honest relationships where we can know that the people who know us best love us most. We want to be loved unconditionally, and not just because we perform adequately or live up to your expectations. We want to be free to agree with you because what youâre saying is reasonable, rather than because youâre the expert. You value me today by embracing me as an equal. So, in short, we recognize that God is love, that he considers every person to be genuinely, innately valuable, and that the whole plan of salvation is God reconciling us through Christ â restoring in us the capacity for relationship, first with him, and secondarily with each other. We recognize that our culture values experience over theory, consensus over authority and belonging over joining. We recognize that to love the people of our culture effectively, so as to draw them to Christ, we must communicate effectively with them, which means communicating with them in a way that is consistent with these assumptions about the culture. This is the foundation of our paradigm. Now, the revolutionary part is the part where we begin to actually do church as if we meant the paragraph above. We have to basically tear up the blueprint for church and start over from that paragraph. Where does that take us? How does all this affect the way we present the gospel, and structure our services and programs? First, we look at our âFrisco Fred and Francineâ demographic model. In addition to the cultural assumptions already stated, we see that they are college-educated, prosperous professionals, probably between the ages of 30 and 50.
